article.description: Illinois seniors Brian Cook and Sean Harrington were too much for North Carolina's talented freshmen.
article.headline: Late Illini run puts game out of reach for Tar Heels
article.linkText: North Carolina runs ot of gas, suffers first loss of year
article.story: CHAMPAIGN, Ill. (AP) -- Brian Cook worked the inside and Sean Harrington handled the outside. Two seniors showing a host of freshmen how it's done. North Carolina's first-year players were impressive at times -- as advertised. And Illinois' crop wasn't bad, either. But it was Cook and Harrington who made the biggest difference as Illinois (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today, No. 25 AP) ran away in the final eight minutes and beat North Carolina (No. 14, No. 12) 92-65 in the ACC/Big Ten Challenge. ''We'll only be as good as Sean and Brian take us,'' Illinois coach Bill Self said. ''Carolina is a little different, playing a lot of young guys. You talk about our youth and they will be good. ... Sean was marvelous and not just because he made his shot. And Brian played to his size. When he plays like that, we have a serious chance to be good.'' Cook scored 22 points and Harrington had a career-high 20, making 6-of-8 3-pointers, to lead the Illini and send Carolina to its first loss. ''I guess if there is a zone, I was pretty close to it,'' Harrington said. ''I felt comfortable. I had a lot of wide-open shots and once I got my feet set, I felt confident I could knock them down. It felt good leaving my hand.'' Illinois (4-0) led 64-57 with 7:42 left and then took off, outscoring the Tar Heels 28-8. North Carolina (5-1) was fresh off a championship in the Preseason NIT. ''We didn't exhibit the poise that we had previously,'' Tar Heels coach Matt Doherty said. ''A lot of times, games come down to matchups and we didn't match up well.'' They had plenty of trouble containing the 6-foot-10 Cook, who was 8-of-12 from the field and had eight rebounds and five assists. Freshman Sean May led North Carolina with 21 points, Jawad Williams had 15 and freshman Rashad McCants 13. ''We were kind of jittery at beginning and once we settled down, I thought our freshmen responded well,'' Cook said. ''They had great players. We knew a lot of the things they wanted to do and just came out and executed.'' Illinois, with five freshmen on its roster, got a splendid game from first-year point guard Dee Brown, who scored 12 points and played stellar defense against North Carolina's Raymond Felton. Harrington sparked an 11-2 second-half run, making a steal and driving layup and then hitting a 3-pointer as Illinois ran off to a 57-45 lead with just under 13 minutes left. May, with his father, former Indiana University star Scott May, watching from a seat several feet behind the Tar Heels bench, then brought Carolina back. He worked inside and made three free throws and an easy layup to cut the lead to 58-52 with just under 10 minutes to go. But Harrington, Luther Head and then Cook hit 3-pointers in a two-minute span, spurring a 15-6 spurt as the Illini broke away to stay, taking a 79-63 lead with four minutes left. ''We'll just use this as a learning experience,'' May said. ''We'll put this game behind us. We're disappointed, but we face another great team (No. 18 Kentucky) on Saturday.'' Harrington's 3-pointer and Head's spectacular dunk on a lob pass from Brown in the final two minutes of the first half helped the Illini take a 40-36 lead. North Carolina jumped out early 11-3. Illinois finally caught up as Harrington's first 3-pointer gave the Illini their first lead, at 19-17, and they went on to build a late eight-point lead. North Carolina rallied and evened the game on a 3-pointer by Jonathan Holmes, before Illinois went up four at the half.
